images.summary: This basement plan shows the layout of the cold cellar and Bedroom 1, including structural components like concrete slabs and masonry chimneys. The plan specifies typical garage and basement floors with 4-inch concrete slabs, 25 MPa concrete, and 6 inches of 3/4-inch washed stone. Walls are designed to step up as grade allows. The masonry chimney has a 14-inch deep footing. Key elements include FW:1 and FW:2 wall types, F:1, F:2, and F:3 footings, C:1 steel post, and B:1 steel beam. Section callouts A/2 and B/2 indicate connections to other views. Dimensions such as 16'-0", 62'-0", and 30'-0" define the layout. The plan includes vinyl siding, rigid insulation, and drywall as key materials.

images.summary: This schedule provides detailed specifications for walls, footings, columns, and beams in the basement. Wall FW:1 includes vinyl siding, a water barrier, rigid insulation, a concrete core, and drywall. FW:2 is an 8-inch poured foundation with a continuous strip footing and vertical rebar. Interior walls W:2 and W:3 feature drywall and 2x4 studs. The footing schedule lists dimensions for F:1, F:2, and F:3, with specific rebar details. Column C:1 is a 3"x3" steel post rated for 41,000 lbs factored load. Beam B:1 is a W 200x31 steel beam. These schedules outline the structural components necessary for the basement level.

images.summary: This schedule outlines the structural components for the ground floor, including wall, column, and beam specifications. Wall W:1 features vinyl siding, an air barrier, rigid insulation, and 2x6 studs. W:2 and W:3 are typical interior walls with drywall and 2x4 studs. W:4 includes optional components like R 20 bats and 6 mil poly. Columns C:1 to C:6 vary from steel posts to fir and plywood configurations. Beam B:1 options include W 10x33 or W 8x48 steel beams, while B:2 is a 10"x12" Douglas Fir beam. The deck includes 4 ply 2x12 P.T. beams and 2x10 joists. The schedule is certified by a professional engineer, S. Desroches, with a license number 10022482, dated January 30, 2025.

images.summary: This main floor plan details the layout of the garage, laundry, mud room, and deck. Key components include vinyl siding, steel beams, and Douglas Fir beams. The garage features self-closing weather strippers, while the laundry area includes drop joists for concrete topping. The plan specifies point loads and structural elements like knee braces and king posts. Section callouts A/2 and B/2 indicate connections to other views. Dimensions such as 16'-0", 62'-0", and 30'-0" define the layout. Element callouts include wall types W:1 to W:4, columns C:1 to C:6, and beams B:1 and B:2.

images.summary: This plan shows the ceiling layout for the second floor, detailing both flat and sloped ceilings. Flat ceilings are insulated with R-60 cellulose, covered with 6 mil poly, and finished with 1/2" drywall. Sloped ceilings use R-31 bats for insulation, also covered with 6 mil poly and 1/2" drywall. The scale of the drawing is 1/4" = 1'-0".

CROSS SECTION A
SCALE: 3/16" = 1'-0"
images.summary: This section view, labeled as 'Cross Section A', illustrates the structural elements of a garage. The roof features vents with a specification of 1 square foot for every 300 square feet of attic space, with 25% at eaves and 25% at the top of the space. The sill assembly includes a sill plate with a 1/4" sill gasket and 1/2" anchor bolts spaced at 4 feet on center, with a minimum embedment of 4 inches. The foundation and footing are detailed, with a 9'-4" height from the top of the foundation to the top of the footing. A 4-inch diameter weeping tile is installed in 6 inches of clear crushed stone, connected to a storm drain. The section is drawn to a scale of 3/16" = 1'-0".

images.summary: This section view, labeled as 'Cross Section B', provides a detailed look at the garage structure. The roof includes vents with a specification of 1 square foot for every 300 square feet of attic space, with 25% at eaves and 25% at the top of the space. The truss core liner is specified with 6 mil poly and R 31 bats. The sill assembly features a sill plate with a 1/4" sill gasket and 1/2" anchor bolts at 4 feet on center, with a minimum embedment of 4 inches. The foundation and footing are detailed, with a height of 13'-3 3/8" from the top of the foundation to the top of the subfloor, and 12'-0" from the top of the footing. A 4-inch diameter weeping tile is installed in 6 inches of clear crushed stone, connected to a storm drain. The section is drawn to a scale of 3/16" = 1'-0".

images.text_verbatim:
BEAM, AS PER PLAN
POST, AS PER PLAN
2'-0"
4x6 BRACE MIN.
NOTCH BEAM 3/4" TO ACCEPT BRACE & FASTEN w/ (1) 3/8"dia. x8" lg. RSS (COUNTERSUNK) (TYP.)
images.summary: This detail shows a structural connection involving a beam, post, and brace. The beam is notched 3/4" to accept the brace and is fastened with a 3/8" diameter, 8" long RSS fastener, countersunk, as typical. The brace is a minimum 4x6 in size. The dimensions of the connection are 2'-0" for both the beam and post, as per the plan. This detail provides specifications for construction detailing, including the use of RSS fasteners.

10x10

2" TENON
CORNER POST, BEAM & BRACE CONNECTION (TYPICAL)
images.summary: This detail illustrates a typical corner post, beam, and brace connection. The connection uses 1.25-inch hardwood dowels and a 2x4 tenon for joining. The post and beam are sized at 10x10 and 10x12 respectively. A 3-foot long 6x6 brace is used, featuring a 1/2-inch shoulder and a 2-inch tenon. The drawing specifies the typical configuration for such connections.

images.summary: This detail shows a beam and post connection using a half lap joint. The connection is reinforced with two 3/8-inch GRK screws embedded a minimum of 4 inches into both the beam and the post at a slight angle. The beam is designed to have a minimum 1-inch direct bearing on the post. The drawing specifies the use of beams and posts as per the plan.

A 3-foot long 6x6 brace is included, featuring a 1/2-inch shoulder and a 2-inch tenon. This configuration is typical for such connections.

FLOOR FRAMING - SEE PLANS
RIM JOIST / BD.

FLASHING TUCKED UNDER TOP PIECE OF SIDING AND LAPPED OVER NEXT CONT. PIECE OF SIDING BELOW

images.summary: This detail shows a deck ledger connection. The floor framing and rim joist are referenced to the plans for specific details. Flashing is tucked under the top piece of siding and lapped over the next continuous piece below. A 90 lb. felt gasket is used on the flashing at lag bolts, which are 1/2-inch bolts spaced 2 inches on center. Foundation and footing sizes are to be determined from the plans.

images.summary: This detail shows the connection between a beam and a post. The beam is to be installed as per the plan, with two 3/8-inch GRK screws embedded a minimum of 4 inches into the beam. The post requires a minimum of 1-inch direct bearing, and two 3/8-inch GRK screws are embedded at a slight angle into the post. The drawing emphasizes the structural integrity of the connection through precise screw placement and bearing requirements.

images.text_verbatim:
4 - GRK TIMBER SCREWS MIN. 3" INTO POST
1" INSET
KING POST TO TRUSS TOP CHORD CONNECTION (TYPICAL)
10x12
6x8
10x10
R = 5'-4 9/16"
POST, BEAM & BRACE CONNECTION (TYPICAL)
images.summary: This detail illustrates typical connections for a king post to truss top chord and a post, beam, and brace. The king post connection uses four GRK timber screws with a minimum 3-inch embedment into the post and a 1-inch inset. The post, beam, and brace connection features dimensions of 10x12, 6x8, and 10x10, with a radius of 5 feet 4 9/16 inches. These connections are typical, emphasizing the structural stability through precise screw placement and component dimensions.
